Joint Sponsorship of Panel Leads to Conflict
Through the efforts of student organizers and Lincoln Gordon,the Homewood
campus wil be the scene today of a panel discussion that shows every indication of developing into an event of
nation-wide prominence.
Though both Dr. Gordon and student
organizers are "pleased" with the result, the same is not being said about the
manner in which it was achieved.
Dr. Gordon spoke of the "unfortunate
way of handling things" which surrounded
the whole incident. Jim Archibald,one of
the principal student organizers, stressed his "hesitancy over ever dealing with
the administration again."
As a result of the work done by Manuel
Rodriguez and Jim Archibald, both Hopkins
undergraduates,
Lincoln
and
Gordon, Noam Chomsky, professor of
linguistics at M.I.T., Herbert Dinerstein,
professor at the Hopkins School of International Studies, W. Averell Harriman,
senior career diplomat and former governor of New York, and Lincoln Gordon
will participate in a panel discussion in
Shriver Hall at 8 p.m. tonight.
Dr. Gordon first approached Rodriguez
on October 26 with the idea of a panel
discussion around the time of the Novem -

ber moratorium, on "how to get out of
Vietnam." Dr. Gordon envisioned the
discussion as one on a high intellectual
level and presenting various points of
view on the war. Dr. Gordon felt that this
balance had been lacking at the October
Moratorium Teach-In.
In the following week it was decided
that the Student Association would sponsor the panel, and that both the students
and the administrationwould each submit
a list of possible speakers for the panel.
The next week, Frederick DeKuyper,
Executive Assistant to the president,
submitted to the students the names of
three SAIS professors. The student organizers indicated that they were thinking
along the lines of Professor Richard
Pfeffer of Political Science, but hadn't
yet drawn up any list.
On Tuesday the 4th, the panelwas tentatively decided for Wednesday (Nov 12),
with Dinnerstein, Harriman,and Pfeffer.
None of the speakers had been confirmed
at this time. Governor Harrimanwas included in the panel when Rodriguez stressed the necessity of having a "drawing
card" or major speaker to attract the
students.
The next day it was discovered that

Harriman could not make the panel on
Wednesday but would be available for
almost anytime on Thursday or Friday.
At this point the panel was moved to Friday.
Wednesday night, the students approached Pfeffer to participate on the
panel. He declined for various reasons
and suggested a number of people they
could try. This led to Archibald and Rodriguez calling Chomsky at his home at
midnight in order to invite him. Chomsky
stated that he would come if itwas physically possible for him to get to Baltimore
after an afternoon speech at Cornell
University. He agreed to call back at 11
the next morning to confirm it.
Thursday morning at 9:30 Archibald
informed Gordon over the phone that
Pfeffer would be unable to make it, but
that the students had been able to secure
Chom sky. Gordon,it is reported by Archibald, became "quite disturbed," and
insisted that Archibald call Chomsky off.
"It's your mistake," Gordon is reported
to have said, "You call him off." Archibald explained that he was not empowered
to do that on his own, and would have to
speak to Rodriguez.
Later that morning, while awaiting

Chomsky's phone call, Rodriguez indicated to DeKuyper that if they could arrange a meeting with Gordon before
Chomsky called back, the situation might
be straightened out. DeKuyper stated that
Gordon was in a very important committee meeting, and that the earliest time
available would be 2 :15 in the afternoon,
which was after Chomsky's verification
was expected. Chomsky was contacted
that morning and verified by Rodriguez
and Archibald.
The afternoon meeting was between
Gordon, Archibald, and Rodriguez. Dr.
Gordon has refused to discuss the content of this meeting, insisting that it was
"a private discussion." The events of the
afternoon became a matter of public record in that Rodriguez and Archibald
were required to report to the Student
Association Cabinet.
According to the two students at the
meeting, Gordon charged that the students displayed a gross lack of courtesy,
to him, but more importantly, to Governor Harriman. He felt that the two had
"violated the ground rules", in that they
had agreed to get Pfeffer, and didn't consult him on their change of plans.

Symposium Panel on CBW Remains Unreconciled
By ART LEVINE
A speech linking criticism of the military to an "international Communist
conspiracy"
highlighted Wednesday's
Milton S. Eisenhower Symposium panel
on chemical and biological warfare
(CBW).
Colonel Norman Shapira, former head
of CBW for the Combat Developments
division of the Army's Institute of Special
Studies, declared that CBW was important for a strong national defense that
would help us resist the "slavery, poverty and perversionwhich are the historical facts of Communism." The panel at
Shriver Hall also heard Seymour Hersh,
author of Chemical and Biological Warfare: America's Hidden Arsenal, and
Congressman Richard McCarthy (D-NY)
criticize
chemical and
biological
weapons.
Congresman McCarthy of Buffalo,
N.Y., the leading Congressional critic of
CBW, lambasted the weapons as dangerous and unnecessary. Noting that the
Defense Department has allocated $400
to $600 million for CBW in 1970, he outlined some of the weapons now being
stockpiled, including the deadly VX nerve
gas, and infectious plague toxins. The
Congresman charged that biological weapons are "unreliable, uncontrollable, and
unpredictable" and could lead to a worldwide epidemic.
McCarthy said that according to testirnony by a member of the Army's Chemical and Biological Research division,
there were plans to develop a synthetic
disease that would be able to resist all
antibiotics. Development of this biological weapon has not gone ahead, McCarthy
said, because funds were cut this year
for chemical and biological weapons.
Defoliants and Protocol
Although he criticized the use of tear
gas as an adjunct to lethal weapons,
Congressman McCarthy said that we
Should maintain a deterrent capability
in deadly chemicals for a limited time.
He said, however, that we should abandon
biological weapons unilaterally. He also
criticized the use of defoliants as harmful to ecology and human life. He pointed
to Cancer Socity research that showed
baby rats were born deformed as a result of their mothers' contacts with the
defoliant 245-L.
Congressman McCarthy observed that
the United States and Japan are the only
two major countries that haven't signed
the Geneva Protocol of 1925, which bans
the use of chemical and biological weapons. He said we have not made it clear
Whether or not we Will use these weapons

offensively, and thus, he charged,we are
eroding the restraint of the 1925 pact.
"The Geneva Protocol of 1925," he said,
"is one of the few successful cases of
mankind getting together to limit weapons. We can build other arms-control
agreements on this one." He added,
"The United States should ratify the
Geneva Protocol."
Seymour Hersh analyzed the history
and present set-up of the CBW program,
charging that it was filled with "doubletalk and double-think." He led off his
comments with an anectode about a doctor working in CBW who introduced himself by saying, "Hi! I'm in plague."
In World War I, Hersh noted, 1.3
million people were killed by poison gas.
He said that the use of this gas escalated during that war. In 1936 the Germans developed nerve gas, but it wasn't
until the 1950's, Hersh said, that the
U.S. started a full scale build-up of CBW
with the help of German and Japanese
scientists. Extensive secrecy has always surrounded the development of
these weapons, Hersh contended.

Trustees Officially Approve Coeducation
The bureaucratic wheels have slowly
turned and the Johns Hopkins University
is now officially a co-educational institution.
Following the recommendation of Dr.
Gordon, who was following the recommendation of the Academic Council, the
Board of Trustees voted last Tuesday to
admit women as Sophomore and Junior
transfers next year.
The decision was formally announced
at a press conference held last Wednesday. Speaking at the conference were Dr.
Lincoln Gordon, Dean Carl Swanson,who
is chairman of a Task-Force committee
appointed to study the problems involved
in implementing co-education, William
Brinkley, Director of Admissions, and
Roger Faxon, a junior who is onthe Task
Force.
Gordon stated that admitting upperclass transfer students does not pose the
kinds of problems that opening admissions to women of the freshman level
would entail, mainly that of housing. He
has appointed the task force to examine
the problems involved, and report back
by February 1, 1970. The school's twoyear residency requirement ruled out the
possibility of admitting senior transfers.
It is generally expected that between
50 and 75 women will be admitted on this

transfer basis. Brinkly felt that"50 could
be counted on," but he wasn't sure about
more than that. He had received two calls
that morning from womenwho expressed
interested in transferring. According to
Brinkly, most interest has been from
girls interested in the sciences.

Local Girl::
Swanson denied that this set-up would
rule out the admission of women as freshman next year. He pointed out that even
without housing, local freshman girls
could be admitted. All of these questions,
according to Swanson, would be decided
by the Task Force, whichwould probably
give two recommendations, one for next
fall and another long-range plan.
Mr. Brinkley, while stating that the admissions office is ready to accept any
transfer applications, pointed out that
it has no provision for taking women's applications for the freshman
class. He did not feel that it would be a
good idea to accept applications from
girls who had been informed that they
might not be able to come due to lack of
facilities, but he did feel that if any decision to admit freshman women was
made at a later date, the February 1
deadline for receiving applications could

be waived.
All present emphasized that the move
to co-education would not cut down on the
exchange programs with Goucher College. It was hoped that the program could
be expanded and perhaps inaugurated with
other schools, such as the Maryland
Institute of Art.

"Healthier Environment"
Swanson, who commented that co-education would provide "a healthier learning environment," pointed out that the
Task Force was not prepared to investigate the philosophy of undergraduate
education. He stated that "We are not a
typical Liberal Arts college," due to
heavy emphasis on graduate work, with
most undergraduates planning to go on
to graduate school of some kind. Hopkins, according to Swanson, provides "an
environment of scholarship, and if you
provide that and have limited resources,
you cannot provide much else."
Besides Swanson and Faxon, the Task
Force committee consists of Dr. James
C. Walker of Physics, Ronald E. Sapp,
director of
administrative systems,
Martin Vogel, a junior, and an undetermined member of the faculty.

The Meeting
Dr. Gordon directed the Assembly to a discussion of
the Allied Health Sciences program. The proposal came
as a result of growing realization of the great shortage
of nurses and medical technicians at the Hopkins Hospital.
It would be an attempt to train people for supervisory
positions, somewhat below the level of physicians but above
the level of today's nurses and medical technicians.
The program would involve admitting into Hopkins,
after two years of college, students who wish to obtain
above-average training for positions as nurses and medical technicians. Those admitted would get their bachelor's degree after two years, and many would hopefully
go on for another one or two years to get their Masters'.
People for this program would be recruited from colleges
throughout the country, rather than just from Hopkins
students.
A major advantage of the training of such sub-professionals was that it would reduce the cost of medical care
(since these subprofessionals would not require as much
costly training as doctors), and that it would produce a
greater number of trained medical workers than are being
produced by current educational methods.

How Deadly the Silent Majority?
This day there can only be the writing of apprehensive
preludes, uneasy scrapings of violin strings and the ominous random rumblings of tympani. Forebodingwhat? We
shall know soon; the strings sing of fear. And indeed it is
a fearful thing to think about tomorrow's March for Peace,
the fear of bloodshed, of cracked heads and broken limbs
(our own), and tear-gassings and god knows what else.
(Would they dare fire shots into the crowd?)(How can you
contain a half-million people in a peaceful posture?)There
will be confrontation. It may be peaceful; it probably will
not. The odds are not at all favorable: the unarmed army
is certain to be outgunned: symbols vs. weapons, spit vs.
mace, pot-smoke vs. tear gas. Yet the unarmed army has
no choice. It shall take casualties no matter what, and besides it must committed to peace.Peace means no violence

for only it can profit from violent confrontation. Washington wishes to discredit the peace movement by showing
that it cannot remain true to its ideals. The burden of
proof rests upon those who are not in power. It is not an
easy task, but it would seem to be one worth trying at least
one last time, just to see if massive peaceful demonstration of a moral position, of a statement of desired national behavior, has any effect whatsoever (in this democratic
society) upon both the people who rule it and the silent
majority Sir Richard is always talking about. There can
be no mistaking the extent of the peace movement if some
half million people are willing to travel however far to
participate in the demonstration. There is no silent majority, simply a figment of some President's imagination.
Here is an active vocal representation of areal presence
in this country that wants a return to peace and national
sanity. Only a fool could ignore such a demonstration.
Indeed.
A few weeks ago The New Republic voiced a tentative
hope that Mr. Nixon would continue to respect public opinion as he had in the past, yieldingto its whim for the sake
of a 'clear mandate.' Yet it seems clear that Nixon has
abandoned that passive role of reading public opinion for
the more powerfully active one of making opinion. It was
reasonably astute of him or one of his advisors to realize
that they could indeed reintroduce a kind of anti-propaganda into the President's speeches, whereby the public
could be duped into believing that it had made up its own
mind while it yielded to the Administration's policies.
Americans in general do not like the idea of being in the
minority, and, what with all of those nasty minorities getting everything for nothing, it was about time that majority rule be re-instituted. What they did not know, however, was how the majority of their fellow Americans
thought. Chances are that their fellow Americans did not
think at all, but if they did it seemed to be apparent for a
while (check the Gallup polls of late summer, early fall)
that the nation was tired of the war and wanted out. Not
so, says Mrs. Nixon.

By GEORGE KIRSCHBAUM
Sports Editor
After ten scoreless quarters and much frustration, the Varity football team turned in one whale of a second half against Swarthmore.
The Varsity Gridders racked up 26 points before the final whistle
blew. In previous weeks,the most unanswerable question was? "What
went wrong?" Yet last Saturday's second half performance pushed
such questions into the background.

Fans Brave Weather
Anyone of the few diehard Hopkins fanswho braved the weather and
could afford the university's unrealistic admissions charge could see
that Sotir's suspicions had been put aside when linebacker Paul Weiss
snagged an errant Mike O'Neal pass and ran it back 40 yards from
Hopkins' third touchdown of the afternoon.
Unlike Lloyd Eaton of Wyoming and John Pont of Indiana who have
had their conference and bowl bids upset by racial and disciplinary
strife, Alex Sotir is riding high.
Just as Red Auerbach used to light up his victory cigar. Sotir broke
out a similar victory smile after Weiss's interception and score.
Hopkins's 4-1 MAC record is the best inthe Southern Division, and
the mightly Black and Blue go.after a piece of the MAC Sothern Division Crown for an unprecedented third straight year.
How did the Blue Jays put it all together? To answer this question
one must turn the clock back to the Jays' first loss of the season against Ursinus. After this 19-14 setback, the format of practice was
changed.
The result was that the young team as a whole was more tense and
felt compelled to win or else be punished in the following week's practice. Back-to-back losses to Hampden-Sydney and Carnegie-Mellon proved that more hittingwasn't the answer. Of course it is doubtful as to whether or not the team would have won these ball games if
the format had not been changed.
Nevertheless, Coach Sotir showed the flexibility that has endeared
him to his players when the team returned to its former format a week
ago last Tuesday. This move restored much of the team's confidence,
and at the end of the week Sotir felt the club "had turned the corner."

Momentum With Jays
In tomorrow's contest at Dickinson, one has to give the momentum
to the Jays. Dickinson,whose defense had been nationally ranked, suffered a humiliating 49-0 loss to Wilkes College followed by a slim 2120 Homecoming loss to Ursinus last Saturday. Dickinson thereby
dropped out of contention for the coveted MAC crown.
After one of Sotir's spirited pep talks last week, one player mused:
"I wonder if he stays up all night figuring out what he's going to say to
the team or whether the talks are just off the cuff?"
It doesn't matter that Hopkins probably won't get a chance to play
in the first Knute Rockne Bowl. For when the team leaves the locker
room at Carlisle tomorrow afternoon, one thought will be dominant.
"LET'S WIN THIS ONE FOR LEX!" In an era, when there seems to
be an equal amount of victimization of coaches by players as players
by coaches (an era, which the Varsity footballteam has luckily escaped) could Charley Eckman or Vince Bagli have put it any better?

To Capture MAC Lead
By MARC HELLER
The Hopkins football team after an impotent
first half came on to defeat Swarthmore last Saturday by the score of 26 to 0. All the Blue Jay
scoring took place in the second half, leading to
a rout of the weak, but battling Swarthmore club.
The first half of the contest was dull, neither
team sustaining an offensive drive. The half
amounted to an exchange of punts between the two
teams. Hopkins did come as close as the Swarthmore 14 yard line, where however, the drive was
halted as a fourth down pass from quarterback
Bob Pfeffer fell incomplete.
Swarthmore, a team which had won only one
game, succumbed to the stronger Blue Jays, in
the second half. Swarthmore had little depth and
bench strength, many of its squad playing both
( Hopkins scored the first time it had the ball
following a Swarthmore punt, after Swarthmore
received the second half kickoff.
Dan Augustine, who was named by Coach Alex
Sotir as the Blue Jays most valuable offensive
player of the game, hauled in a pass from Bob
Pfeiffer and carried the ball to the Swarthmore
32 yard line. After a run to the 18 yard line which
gave Hopkins another first down, Augustine was
handed the ball on an option play, and threw to end
Bill Donovan to the three yard line.
A motion penalty brought the ball back to the
Swarthmore 8, where on three downs Hopkins was
unable to move the ball. On fourth down, the Blue
Jays lined up to kick a field goal. Bob Pfeiffer,
holding on the play, took the snapfrom center and
fired a pass to Bill Utz for the touchdown.

Try Fake Field Goal
The fake field goal had caught Swarthmore off

guard. This play,the first Hopkins' score in eleven
quarters, provided the incentive for the Blue Jays,
as they began to play a more potent brand of football.
The key play of the game for the Blue Jays may
have been the 40 yard interception and runback
of a Swarthmore pass by linebacker Paul Weiss.
Weiss is the leading groundgainer of the team this
year. Weiss who had ankle problems, was not
actually up to par physically to play fullback.
This fine defensive play may then have re -instilled a new spirit in the club which is essential to the Hopkins club winning the conference
title.

Cieslowski Races 63 Yds
Hopkins final score came on a 63 yard run by
Joe Cieslowski late in the fourth quarter. Cieslowski ran off tackle, made a beautiful cut to
the outside, and outraced the Swarthmore defensive backs for the score. Here for the first time
in three weeks, a smile came to the lips of Coach
Sotir.
Bob Pfeiffer ran the option play for 53 yards in
the 3rd quarter to account for the 2nd Hopkins
touchdown.
The execution of the offensive unit was much
sharper in the second half and the defense played strongly throughout the contest.
The game next week against Dickinson is most
crucial to the Blue Jays if their hope for a third
Conference title is to be realized. The ability of
the offense and defense to make the big play, as
evidenced in the Swarthmore game, must be repeated in the Dickinson contest. However, the
spirit and pride of the team has been renewed,
and this will be a definite factor in Hopkins favor.

hopes for a league title ended as the Jays were
edged 1-0 by a tough Washington College team.
The Hopkins defense was at its usualfine level,
but the game saw little in the way of a strong Jay
offensive attack. "The front line didn't shoot enough," were co-captain randy Miller's words.

possession of the ball. There was little offensive
punch on either team. The Blue Jay booters didn't
get any shots off in this half while Washington got
off 3.

offense woke up only slightly, still attemptingonly
two shots at the Washington goal. The Sho'men
picked their attack up somewhat as they had ten
shots in this half.

seemed content to let them do it again. However,

halfback Barry Drew. The shot from outside the
penalty area went over the Hopkins defense and
curved towards the left side of the net. Goalie
Steve Weiss got a hand on the ball, but it spun off
his fingertips and went into the net with 5:15 elapsed in the fourth quarter.

they played inspired soccer from them on.
they played inspired soccer from then on.

game. We came to play and wanted the game. We

fine shot to beat us. It was a tough loss, but I hope
we will be able to bounce back and take the final
two games of the season."
The team will have to polish up its offense this
week. The line, hampered somewhat by injuries,
has not been especially productive in recent games
and has a long way to go to shape up. Two shots is
just not enough to win any ball game.The defense
has been playing well all season letting in only six
goals in eight games, but they cannot be expected
to carry the whole load.

The booters travel to Philadelphia tomorrow for
an 11:30 game with Drexel Tech. Drexel has had an
unusually diappointing season, not yet havingwon,

On Tuesday, the Western Maryland Green
Terrors will come to Homewood for a 3:00 p.m.
game on the soccer field. The Terrors are not an
especially strong team, but have played some good
games. The Jays will have to expect a tough contest.
The Blue Jays are now 5-2-1 for the season,

By GEORGE KIRSCHBAUM
Sports Editor
After ten scoreless quarters and much frustration, the Varity football team turned in one whale of a second half against Swarthmore.
The Varsity Gridders racked up 26 points before the final whistle
blew. In previous weeks,the most unanswerable question was? "What
went wrong?" Yet last Saturday's second half performance pushed
such questions into the background.

Fans Brave Weather
Anyone of the few diehard Hopkins fanswho braved the weather and
could afford the university's unrealistic admissions charge could see
that Sotir's suspicions had been put aside when linebacker Paul Weiss
snagged an errant Mike O'Neal pass and ran it back 40 yards from
Hopkins' third touchdown of the afternoon.
Unlike Lloyd Eaton of Wyoming and John Pont of Indiana who have
had their conference and bowl bids upset by racial and disciplinary
strife, Alex Sotir is riding high.
Just as Red Auerbach used to light up his victory cigar. Sotir broke
out a similar victory smile after Weiss's interception and score.
Hopkins's 4-1 MAC record is the best inthe Southern Division, and
the mightly Black and Blue go.after a piece of the MAC Sothern Division Crown for an unprecedented third straight year.
How did the Blue Jays put it all together? To answer this question
one must turn the clock back to the Jays' first loss of the season against Ursinus. After this 19-14 setback, the format of practice was
changed.
The result was that the young team as a whole was more tense and
felt compelled to win or else be punished in the following week's practice. Back-to-back losses to Hampden-Sydney and Carnegie-Mellon proved that more hittingwasn't the answer. Of course it is doubtful as to whether or not the team would have won these ball games if
the format had not been changed.
Nevertheless, Coach Sotir showed the flexibility that has endeared
him to his players when the team returned to its former format a week
ago last Tuesday. This move restored much of the team's confidence,
and at the end of the week Sotir felt the club "had turned the corner."

Momentum With Jays
In tomorrow's contest at Dickinson, one has to give the momentum
to the Jays. Dickinson,whose defense had been nationally ranked, suffered a humiliating 49-0 loss to Wilkes College followed by a slim 2120 Homecoming loss to Ursinus last Saturday. Dickinson thereby
dropped out of contention for the coveted MAC crown.
After one of Sotir's spirited pep talks last week, one player mused:
"I wonder if he stays up all night figuring out what he's going to say to
the team or whether the talks are just off the cuff?"
It doesn't matter that Hopkins probably won't get a chance to play
in the first Knute Rockne Bowl. For when the team leaves the locker
room at Carlisle tomorrow afternoon, one thought will be dominant.
"LET'S WIN THIS ONE FOR LEX!" In an era, when there seems to
be an equal amount of victimization of coaches by players as players
by coaches (an era, which the Varsity footballteam has luckily escaped) could Charley Eckman or Vince Bagli have put it any better?

The Hopkins football team after an impotent
first half came on to defeat Swarthmore last Saturday by the score of 26 to 0. All the Blue Jay
scoring took place in the second half, leading to
a rout of the weak, but battling Swarthmore club.
The first half of the contest was dull, neither
team sustaining an offensive drive. The half
amounted to an exchange of punts between the two
teams. Hopkins did come as close as the Swarthmore 14 yard line, where however, the drive was
halted as a fourth down pass from quarterback
Bob Pfeffer fell incomplete.
Swarthmore, a team which had won only one
game, succumbed to the stronger Blue Jays, in
the second half. Swarthmore had little depth and
bench strength, many of its squad playing both
( Hopkins scored the first time it had the ball
following a Swarthmore punt, after Swarthmore
received the second half kickoff.
Dan Augustine, who was named by Coach Alex
Sotir as the Blue Jays most valuable offensive
player of the game, hauled in a pass from Bob
Pfeiffer and carried the ball to the Swarthmore
32 yard line. After a run to the 18 yard line which
gave Hopkins another first down, Augustine was
handed the ball on an option play, and threw to end
Bill Donovan to the three yard line.
A motion penalty brought the ball back to the
Swarthmore 8, where on three downs Hopkins was
unable to move the ball. On fourth down, the Blue
Jays lined up to kick a field goal. Bob Pfeiffer,
holding on the play, took the snapfrom center and
fired a pass to Bill Utz for the touchdown.

Try Fake Field Goal
The fake field goal had caught Swarthmore off

guard. This play,the first Hopkins' score in eleven
quarters, provided the incentive for the Blue Jays,
as they began to play a more potent brand of football.
The key play of the game for the Blue Jays may
have been the 40 yard interception and runback
of a Swarthmore pass by linebacker Paul Weiss.
Weiss is the leading groundgainer of the team this
year. Weiss who had ankle problems, was not
actually up to par physically to play fullback.
This fine defensive play may then have re -instilled a new spirit in the club which is essential to the Hopkins club winning the conference
title.

Cieslowski Races 63 Yds
Hopkins final score came on a 63 yard run by
Joe Cieslowski late in the fourth quarter. Cieslowski ran off tackle, made a beautiful cut to
the outside, and outraced the Swarthmore defensive backs for the score. Here for the first time
in three weeks, a smile came to the lips of Coach
Sotir.
Bob Pfeiffer ran the option play for 53 yards in
the 3rd quarter to account for the 2nd Hopkins
touchdown.
The execution of the offensive unit was much
sharper in the second half and the defense played strongly throughout the contest.
The game next week against Dickinson is most
crucial to the Blue Jays if their hope for a third
Conference title is to be realized. The ability of
the offense and defense to make the big play, as
evidenced in the Swarthmore game, must be repeated in the Dickinson contest. However, the
spirit and pride of the team has been renewed,
and this will be a definite factor in Hopkins favor.

Johns Hopkins varsity soccer team had their
hopes for a league title ended as the Jays were
edged 1-0 by a tough Washington College team.
The Hopkins defense was at its usualfine level,
but the game saw little in the way of a strong Jay
offensive attack. "The front line didn't shoot enough," were co-captain randy Miller's words.

possession of the ball. There was little offensive
punch on either team. The Blue Jay booters didn't
get any shots off in this half while Washington got
off 3.

offense woke up only slightly, still attemptingonly
two shots at the Washington goal. The Sho'men
picked their attack up somewhat as they had ten
shots in this half.

Weiss had saved the Loyola game, and the team
seemed content to let them do it again. However,
as one observer said, "The defense could only do
so much for so long."
Washington's goal came on a powerful kick by
halfback Barry Drew. The shot from outside the
penalty area went over the Hopkins defense and
curved towards the left side of the net. Goalie
Steve Weiss got a hand on the ball, but it spun off
his fingertips and went into the net with 5:15 elapsed in the fourth quarter.
The goal gave the Sho'men renewed spirit as
they played inspired soccer from them on.
they played inspired soccer from then on.
Hopkins coach Bob Knauff commented on the
game," On the whole the team played a fine ball
game. We came to play and wanted the game. We
weren't able to get as many shots though.It took a
fine shot to beat us. It was a tough loss, but I hope
we will be able to bounce back and take the final
two games of the season."
The team will have to polish up its offense this
week. The line, hampered somewhat by injuries,
has not been especially productive in recent games
and has a long way to go to shape up. Two shots is
just not enough to win any ball game.The defense
has been playing well all season letting in only six
goals in eight games, but they cannot be expected
to carry the whole load.

The booters travel to Philadelphia tomorrow for
an 11:30 game with Drexel Tech. Drexel has had an
unusually diappointing season, not yet havingwon,

On Tuesday, the Western Maryland Green
Terrors will come to Homewood for a 3:00 p.m.
game on the soccer field. The Terrors are not an
especially strong team, but have played some good
games. The Jays will have to expect a tough contest.
The Blue Jays are now 5-2-1 for the season,
and 2-1-1 in the league. The league title is now

Hospital and nursing homes are demanding and receiving
"kickbacks" from drugstores to provide prescriptions
under Federal health programs, a spokesman for the
American Pharmaceutical Association claimed this week.
Jacob W. Miller, chairman of the association's public
affairs committee, testified before the House Ways and
Means Committee that cash was passed under the table
from drugstore owners to institutions to win lucrative
drug contracts in Medicare and Medicaid programs. Miller said that the kickback demands was being made "in
every state."
The kickback practice has contributed to the high costs
of drugs, Miller stated, because the druggist normalY
raises his prices to other customers to meet the kickback cost. "The most bitter complaints we have received
are from pharmacists who have, in fact, been subjected
to kickback demands," Miller added.
Nearly $50 million in prescriptions are dispensed
annually to nursing homes and other extended care facilities under the Medicare program. In turn, the hospitals
are reimbursed for the "in patient" drug costs. A Medicare patient who is not hospitalized cannot be reimbursed

March Permit
Federal authorities and anti-war leaders agreed Tuesday on a compromise route for the mass protest march
on Saturday which will allow demonstrators to parade for
2 1/2 hours along Pennsylvania Avenue but not past the
White House.
Granting the Pennsylvania Avenue route was a major
retreat for the government. Last Friday the Justice Department, warning of a "substantial likelihood of serious
violence," flately barred such a route. The government
and representatives of the New Mobilization Committee
to End the War in Vietnam had been at an impasse for
more than a week over the marching permit.
Mayor Walter Washington has been creditedwith breaking the deadlock. On Monday he met with President Nixon
and assured t e President that the city is well-prepared
to handle the influx of anti-war protestors. A statement
released by the deputy U.S. attorney general claimed that
"the probability of any marked violence has now been
materially reduced", without elaborating on their "information" last week that some protestors intended to provoke disorders.
Meanwhile, paratroopers began landing this week in
Washington to be ready for possible disorders over the
weekend. About 2,000 paratroopers are stationed in the
capital area to supplement the 9,000 District of Columbia,
National Guardsmen assigned for the Moratorium demonstrations. Anti-war leaders expect 500,000 protestors in
Washington tomorrow.
